questions.question: What is a bias?

choices.answer: A scientific observation of a   natural process that occurs   on earth
A non-scientific prediction     about something in the natural world

questions.question: Scientists perform experiments using the scientific method in order to

choices.answer: Answer questions about the natural world
Determine if their predictions about the natural world are   correct
Generate evidence upon       which we can build scientific knowledge

questions.question: What is a hypothesis?

choices.answer: A random guess that turns    out to be correct
A thoughtful prediction to what you think will happen in an experiment
A qualitative observation      made during an experiment
A quantitative observation   made during an experiment

questions.question: What is a controlled experiment?

choices.answer: An experiment in which only one variable is changed
An experiment in which you measure at least two different things
An experiment in which you change or manipulate at least two variables
An experiment that does not involve making qualitative observations

questions.question: What is analyzing data?

choices.answer: Looking for relationships, patterns, and solutions in things tested
Forming a hypothesis based on data collected during an experiment
Getting rid of bad data in an experiment
Making observations that lead to collection of data in an experiment

questions.question: What is data?

choices.answer: A conclusion based on measurements made during an experiment
An analysis of measurements made during an experiment

questions.question: What is the scientific method?

choices.answer: A way to make observations about a living thing
A procedure that directs how to conduct a scientific experiment
The process of solving a problem
Making inferences based on non-scientific observations

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a scientific observation?

choices.answer: The dog has a mass of 70 kilograms
A tree with colorful leaves is beautiful

questions.question: What is an observation?

choices.answer: An explanation for something you see in the natural world
A description of a natural cycle or scientific idea
Something you notice, measure or detect
Something you have a strong like for

questions.question: What is an inference?

choices.answer: An opinion about a scientific idea
An argument that supports a scientific idea
An idea or prediction formed from facts or evidence
A qualitative observation that describes an organisms behavior

questions.question: A good controlled experiment has

choices.answer: One experimental group and more than one control
Multiple experimental groups and no control
Multiple experimental groups and one control

questions.question: What do you call the variable you change or manipulate?
Which of the following is an example of a qualitative observation?
Which of the following is an example of a quantitative observation?
What is a variable?

choices.answer: A prediction about what you think will happen in an experiment
A quantitative observation of something in the natural      world
The time it takes to complete an experiment
A factor or condition in an experiment

questions.question: Which piece of lab equipment should you use to measure distance or length?
During a lab investigation, you should NEVER

choices.answer: Point the opening of containers away from yourself and others
Mix unknown substances or chemicals together

questions.question: What should you do if you break a glass container or spill a chemical?

choices.answer: Clean it up with your hands

questions.question: Which piece of safety equipment is most helpful in protecting your hands when handling chemicals, glass, or specimens?
Which piece of lab equipment should you use to measure the volume of liquids?
What tool would be best to determine how much matter is in an object?
What are the metric units for length?
What are the metric units for temperature?
Which type of graph is useful when you want to show how one variable changes over time?
Why is it important that scientists adhere to a code of ethics?

choices.answer: Scientists can get into trouble if they do not perform honest research
Scientists can lose the public's trust
Scientists are more likely to perform
